meanings.def: having a hole or empty space inside
examples: a hollow ball/centre/tube/tree
a hollow metal cylinder
The tree trunk was hollow inside.
Her stomach felt hollow with fear.
I felt hollow from lack of food.
The experience left her feeling hollow and empty.
I tapped the tin and it sounded hollow.
hollow eyes/cheeks
hollow-eyed from lack of sleep

meanings.def: making a low sound like that made by an empty object when it is hit
examples: a hollow groan
I've had enough of their hollow promises.
She gave a slightly hollow laugh.
Their appeals for an end to the violence had a hollow ring.
He won something of a hollow victory when his opponent was forced to withdraw with a serious injury.

meanings.def: to give the impression of not being sincere or true
examples: His expressions of support rang rather hollow.
His promise rang hollow.

meanings.def: to give the impression of being sincere/true or not sincere/true
examples: It may seem a strange story but it rings true to me.
His expressions of support rang rather hollow.
His promise rang hollow.

idioms.def: to give the impression of not being sincere or true
examples: His expressions of support rang rather hollow.
His promise rang hollow.

idioms.def: to give the impression of being sincere/true or not sincere/true
examples: It may seem a strange story but it rings true to me.
His expressions of support rang rather hollow.
His promise rang hollow.

meanings.def: an area that is lower than the surface around it, especially on the ground
examples: All but one of the ponds are empty, their sites marked only by muddy hollows.
The wheelbarrow got stuck in a hollow.
The village lay secluded in a hollow of the hills (= a small valley).
She noticed the slight hollows under his cheekbones.
Snow lay in dark hollows.
a hollow in the ground
the hollow of her throat

meanings.def: a hole or an empty space inside something
examples: The squirrel disappeared into a hollow at the base of the tree.
She suddenly felt a hollow in her stomach, and longed for a friendly face.

meanings.def: to make a flat surface go inward in a curve
examples: be hollowed (by something) The stairs have been hollowed by centuries of use.
